discourse_list.title: The Bear's Silver Lining: DAI Enters The Top 10

content.content: As the title suggests - this is something to celebrate despite the market’s kamikaze dive:  Screen Shot 2022-06-15 at 9.08.45 PM1496×806 78.4 KB   Screen Shot 2022-06-15 at 9.10.03 PM1502×810 83.2 KB  On top of that milestone, the ongoing market crash contains some genuine bright spots from Maker’s perspective:  Endless liquidations going off without a hitch, decentralised systems working under pressure While massive centralised (and decentralised) lenders are going bust, Maker looks rock solid The surplus buffer is at 82m, up from 71m just a month ago (a silver lining of those liquidations!) Organic DAI demand continues to rise, while most other stablecoins struggle   Lots of reasons to be optimistic about Maker amidst this bear. Onwards!

The only issue is that most of that demand is non revenue generating stablecoin backed DAI.  People are selling their crypto and turning to DAI to hold value while other coins go down.  Those who hold DAI are probably waiting for low enough prices to buy back into other coins.  What I’m worried about is that usd rates becomes too attractive and DAI starts to get converted to usd.  That’s when you start to lose demand forever.  Waiting anxiously for the ability to invest portions of the PSMs into bonds.  MKR has a special ability to profit during upturns and downturns.  We are very close to making it happen sustainably.

Following this, Maker have two faces, the bull face when it earns a lot from SF, and the Bear face when it earns from liquidations, I think in this case (bear) Maker could focus on showing how someone can be profitable liquidating Vaults (of course needs to be someone with lot of money), but not much ppl knows how to do this, so is a good idea to try and explain in the easiest way to people how to be a Keeper of how to liquidate with other interface (if there are).

This is a good point, DeFi’s liquidation processes are not particularly well understood. However I think Maker has gone a long way to streamline these over the last year or two, and I don’t think we’ve had an issue with inefficient liquidations since the big crash in early 2020. Sophisticated players will be automating most of this process across DeFi, is my operating assumption.
